aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Analysis - Ryan Navion in Broomfield, Colorado
The accident occurred in Broomfield, Colorado.
The accident occurred on March 15, 2013, at 14:08 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Ryan Navion.
The defining event of the accident was loss of lift.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN13LA199.
The aircraft registration was N4276K.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 4 occupants in the aircraft.
No injuries occurred in the accident.
The pilot retracted the landing gear after takeoff from a 9,000-foot runway.
The airspeed dropped shortly after the landing gear was retracted.
An excessive descent rate followed the airspeed drop.
The pilot lowered the landing gear and landed the airplane on the runway.
The airplane departed the runway after landing.
The nose gear collapsed after the airplane departed the runway.
The pilot attributed the excessive descent rate to wind shear.
Weather information obtained by the pilot before the flight indicated gusting wind conditions.
Weather information obtained by the pilot before the flight indicated variable wind conditions.
Weather information obtained by the pilot before the flight indicated turbulent wind conditions.
The flight occurred at a high density altitude.
The pilot should have been aware that conditions were favorable for wind shear.
The pilot should have applied a wind/gust correction factor to the takeoff speed.
Applying a wind/gust correction factor would have maintained a safe airspeed margin.
Applying a wind/gust correction factor would have maintained airplane climb performance.
The airplane's climb performance was degraded by the effects of density altitude.
The airplane was in an overweight condition.
The overweight condition was due to the pilot's erroneous weight and balance calculations.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's inadequate preflight planning.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's decision to take off at a high density altitude and in gusting wind conditions.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Broomfield, Colorado

## Date & Time: 
March 15, 2013, 14:08 Local

## Aircraft:
Ryan Navion

## Defining Event:
Loss of lift

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN13LA199

## Registration:
N4276K

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
4 None

## Analysis

After takeoff from a 9,000-foot runway, the pilot retracted the landing gear. Shortly thereafter, the airspeed dropped, followed by an excessive descent rate. The pilot lowered the landing gear and landed the airplane on the runway before it departed the runway and the nose gear collapsed. The pilot attributed the excessive descent rate to wind shear. The weather information obtained by the pilot before the flight indicated gusting, variable, and turbulent wind conditions at a high density altitude, so the pilot should have been aware that conditions were favorable for wind shear. Further, the pilot should have applied a wind/gust correction factor to the takeoff speed to maintain a safe airspeed margin and to maintain airplane climb performance. The airplane's climb performance was further degraded by the effects of density altitude and the overweight condition of the airplane due to the pilot's erroneous weight and balance calculations.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's inadequate preflight planning and decision to take off at a high density altitude and in gusting wind conditions.

---
